page.paragraph: Now listen to a conversation between two students.
We have that paper to write for Professor Hadley's class.
I know, and I'm not looking forward to doing it.
You mean you haven't even started yours yet?
Well, I wanted to ask you how you're going to go about it.
What do you mean? We're supposed to write a paper, so I'm going to sit down and write it.
You're not going to outline your paper first before you write it?
No, I don't usually make outlines, unless the outline is part of the assignment. You really do?
Yes, I do. I usually spend a lot of time making an outline before I write something. I've been working on the outline for this paper for a couple of days now.
You've already spent a couple of days on the outline for this paper? I can't believe that. I can't believe you need to spend several days making an outline for this assignment.

That's what I need to do to make sure that my paper's really organized. You know the professor said that he wanted a really well-organized paper, don't you? How are you going to make sure that your paper's well-organized if you don't make a detailed outline before you write the paper?
Well, I just write it first, and look at what I've written, and then if I need to, I organize it some more.
